title: Cities told to take control back from Google
text:
Governments should keep control of public transport data so they can develop efficient services and private companies such as Google – which provides free transport information on its website – should have to pay for the data if they want to use it, Mr Mallet said.

"We have a new law passed in France on mobility solutions which is about to be voted where all the services existing in a city have to open their data to the city, but the city does not have to open it to the rest of the world," he said.

The French group generates annual revenue of around $835 million in Australia and New Zealand. It operates buses, trams and ferries and on-demand shuttles in Australia, and expanded into New Zealand in August after buying bus services in Auckland and Wellington.

The Moovizy app on trial in France's St Eitienne gives users many different transport options.

Expanding cities like Sydney need to provide multi-modal transport options, particularly to people living far away from city centres, he said. "It's becoming a key element of the quality of life."

In France, Transdev is using buses to get people living in rural areas to train stations.

Buses with wifi now pick up passengers from parking lots near freeways that lead into Paris from the south and take them to the high-speed train station at Massy. This system has reduced congestion around train stations, Mr Mallet said.

Transdev is increasing the number of electric buses it operates today from 600 (including 200 around Amsterdam's Schiphol airport) to an expected 1400 by 2023.

It is also experimenting with autonomous vehicles in partnership with carmaker Renault in the French city of Rouen.

Autonomous cars and shuttles are likely to work best if they are used on dedicated lanes or dedicated zones so that they can be monitored with cameras from a control room that can slow the vehicles down or stop them if necessary, Mr Mallet said.
description: Cities, not Google, should tell residents the best ways of getting around, says Transdev's global CEO.
